children: Pyelonephritis is associated with the abrupt onset of fever, chills, nausea, and flank or abdominal pain. Hypotension and septic shock may occur.

Presence of bacteriuria and pyuria is the gold standard for the diagnosis of pyelonephritis. Obtain urine cultures for all patients and blood cultures for significantly ill patients. Imaging studies are indicated only for patients in whom an alternative diagnosis or a urologic complication is suspected.
For patients with uncomplicated infection who are able to tolerate oral therapy, select ciprofloxacin for 7 days or levofloxacin for 5 days. Treat complicated infection for 14 days.

Inpatient parenteral antimicrobial options include a fluoroquinolone, extended-spectrum cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefepime) or extended-spectrum penicillins (piperacillin-tazobactam), or a carbapenem (meropenem, imipenem, or ertapenem).

Follow-up urine cultures are indicated only in pregnant women.
